dt: {bc}an event or a time marked by an event that begins a new period or development
{bc}an extended period of time usually characterized by a distinctive development or by a memorable series of events
{bc}a division of geologic time less than a period and greater than an age
{bc}an instant of time or a date selected as a point of reference (as in astronomy)

pt: {sc}period{/sc} {sc}epoch{/sc} {sc}era{/sc} {sc}age{/sc} mean a division of time. {sc}period{/sc} may designate an extent of time of any length.
{sc}epoch{/sc} applies to a period begun or set off by some significant or striking quality, change, or series of events.

pt.t: the steam engine marked a new {it}epoch{/it} in industry

pt: {sc}era{/sc} suggests a period of history marked by a new or distinct order of things.
{sc}age{/sc} is used frequently of a fairly definite period dominated by a prominent figure or feature.

et: Medieval Latin {it}epocha{/it}, from Greek {it}epochē{/it} cessation, fixed point, from {it}epechein{/it} to pause, hold back, from {it}epi-{/it} + {it}echein{/it} to hold {ma}{mat|scheme:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: an event or a time marked by an event that begins a new period or development
an extended period of time usually characterized by a distinctive development or by a memorable series of events
